I'd be happy to explain the math behind the probability calculation. Bayes' theorem states that the probability of a product being high-quality (H) given a sequence of high-quality products (S) is proportional to the probability of the sequence given that the product is high-quality (P(S|H)) times the prior probability of the product being high-quality (P(H)) divided by the probability of the sequence given that the product is low-quality (P(S|~H)) times the prior probability of the product being low-quality (P(~H)). In this case, P(H) is 0.8, P(~H) is 0.2, and P(S|H) is 1 (since all products in the sequence are high-quality). P(S|~H) is the probability of 14 consecutive high-quality products given that the product is low-quality, which is (0.8^14). Therefore, the probability of a product being high-quality given the sequence is approximately 98.67% (14/15).
